issues.title: Merge 5-10k bucket with 2-5k bucket
issues.description:
Merge the 5,000-10,000 pageview bucket with the 2,000-5,000 bucket. Call the combined bucket '>2,000'. This avoids having 'sex worker' as one of the top two results.

[Migrated from beads: career-images-wwb]

issues.title: Add Openverse integration for finding diverse replacement images
issues.description: [Migrated from beads: career-images-wq1]

issues.title: Add link to source page on thumbnails
issues.description:
Add a link to the original source page for each thumbnail. The thumbnail alone doesn't always show the full context of the photo (e.g., is this a stock photo, editorial, documentary context?).

[Migrated from beads: career-images-t1a]

issues.title: Split 'not applicable' into more specific statuses
issues.description:
Current 'not_applicable' status is too broad. Split into:
- 'not_a_career' - item shouldn't be in the dataset (data quality issue)
- 'gender_specific' - truly gender-specific role where diverse imagery doesn't apply

This helps distinguish data cleanup from legitimate exclusions.

[Migrated from beads: career-images-ly5]

issues.title: Build test infrastructure for career-images scripts
issues.description:
Currently the scripts have no automated tests. Need to add test infrastructure to ensure reliability.

Recommended approach:
- Use pytest as testing framework
- Add pytest to pyproject.toml dependencies
- Create tests/ directory structure
- Test categories needed:
  1. Unit tests for individual functions (parsing, calculations, data transformations)
  2. Integration tests with mocked API responses (Wikidata, Wikipedia pageviews)
  3. End-to-end tests with small datasets

Key areas to test:
- list-fetcher.py:
  - SPARQL query generation
  - Wikipedia title extraction and encoding/decoding
  - Pageview data parsing and calculation
  - JSON output format validation
- list-enrich.py:
  - JSON data loading
  - Sorting/filtering logic
  - CSV export format
  - Search functionality
  - Statistics calculations

Mock strategy:
- Mock requests.get() for API calls
- Use fixture data for Wikidata/Wikipedia responses
- Create small test datasets (5-10 articles)

This will enable confident refactoring and prevent regressions as features are added.

[Migrated from beads: career-images-k0c]

issues.title: Strategy for fixing 'not a career' items in Wikidata
issues.description:
When we mark something as 'not a career', it's often because Wikidata has issues like:

1. Wrong Q-ID being used as P106 (e.g., Q43412 'Apostles in the New Testament' instead of Q15699988 'apostle' as a title)
2. Items that aren't really occupations being used as P106 values
3. Disambiguation issues

Need to figure out:
- Should we generate a report of 'not a career' items for Wikidata cleanup?
- Can we suggest the correct Q-ID when one exists?
- Should we have a 'report to Wikidata' workflow?
- How to track which items we've reported/fixed upstream?

[Migrated from beads: career-images-eih]

issues.title: Post to Women in Red for input on tool
issues.description:
Post to Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Women in Red asking:

1. Are there existing efforts on career article image diversity?
2. Any pointers/thoughts on how to best deploy/improve the tool?

Approach: Come as peer seeking advice, not presenting finished product. Share motivation, what's been built, current state, open questions.

Demo at: career-images.fly.dev

Context from brainstorm:
- WIR is the most active topic-based WikiProject (34k+ comments, 1200+ editors)
- User has existing relationships there
- Much better entry point than dormant WikiProject Occupations

[Migrated from beads: career-images-e24]

issues.title: Create tool to audit previously-added images: identify which uploaded images are no longer in their articles
issues.description:
Need a way to track and audit images that were previously uploaded/added to Wikipedia articles to see which ones have been removed or replaced.

Requirements:
- Take a list/record of images that were previously added (need to determine format)
- For each image, check if it's still present in the target article
- Report which images are no longer there
- Possibly include reasons/history (was it replaced? removed? article deleted?)

Implementation considerations:
- Use Wikipedia API to fetch current article images
- Compare against historical record of what was added
- May need to track: article name, image filename, date added
- Could use Wikipedia revision history API to determine when/why removed

This helps measure the impact and persistence of the diversity improvements made through this tool.

[Migrated from beads: career-images-cfx]

issues.title: Ensure tool output is web-accessible (investigate if Google Sheets integration is sufficient or if additional web interface is needed)
issues.description: [Migrated from beads: career-images-byc]

issues.title: Upload wizard link should use attribution from source photo/Openverse
issues.description:
The upload wizard link appears to use text that isn't drawn from the actual source photo or Openverse metadata. Should pull creator, license, source URL from Openverse API response.

[Migrated from beads: career-images-bux]

issues.title: Sort by pageview buckets, alphabetically within bucket
issues.description:
Instead of sorting by exact daily pageview count, group careers into percentile buckets and sort alphabetically within each bucket. Display the bucket range instead of exact counts.

Example:
- Instead of showing 'sex worker: 8,113 daily views'
- Show 'sex worker: 8,000-12,000 views' (sorted alphabetically with other 8k-12k careers)

Rationale: The goal is to highlight high-traffic career articles that could benefit from diverse imagery, not to create an exact ranking. Alphabetical within buckets feels more neutral and makes browsing easier.

Implementation notes:
- Define ~10-15 buckets (e.g., 10k+, 5k-10k, 2k-5k, 1k-2k, 500-1k, 200-500, 100-200, 50-100, <50)
- Sort by bucket descending, then alphabetically within bucket
- Show bucket range in UI instead of exact count
- Consider making buckets configurable or using log scale

[Migrated from beads: career-images-boh]

issues.title: Add Google Sheets integration for tracking reviewed articles
issues.description:
Implement Google Sheets integration for tracking reviewed articles using gspread (https://gspread.org). Inspiration: https://parkerhiggins.net/2025/05/google-sheets-database-for-projects/

Required columns (per spec.md):
- Wikidata category (job/profession/occupation/position)
- Average daily page views (2024)
- Page name with link to Wikipedia article
- Thumbnails (URLs as text, regenerated for HTML display)
- Reviewed (boolean flag, manually set)
- Non-diverse (boolean flag for inherently non-diverse roles like pope)

Workflow:
- Phase 1 script should populate Google Sheet with lightweight data for ALL articles
- Sheet serves as persistent database and manual review interface
- Human reviewers update flags directly in the sheet
- Later phases read from sheet to determine which articles to process next

Dependencies:
- Add gspread library to pyproject.toml
- Will need Google Sheets API credentials/authentication

[Migrated from beads: career-images-bks]

issues.title: Fix Commons upload wizard link - parameters not working
issues.description:
The upload wizard link goes to a page that doesn't seem to accept/use the parameters we're passing. Investigate the correct URL format for pre-filling the wizard.

[Migrated from beads: career-images-bjw]

issues.title: Find or write Wikipedia essay on NPOV (Neutral Point of View) when applied to images/pictures
issues.description:
Wikipedia's NPOV policy is typically discussed in terms of article text, but image selection also has POV implications. For this project (improving diversity in career article images), we need to understand or articulate how NPOV applies to visual representation.

Research:
- Search for existing Wikipedia essays/discussions on image neutrality
- Look for discussions about representation, diversity, and NPOV in images
- Check Wikipedia:Neutral point of view and related policy pages
- Review Wikipedia talk pages for discussions on this topic

Goal:
- Either find an existing essay that addresses this
- Or write/draft one that explains the problem space
- Document the policy/philosophical framework for why diverse representation in career images matters within Wikipedia's guidelines

This will provide important context and justification for the work being done by this tool.

[Migrated from beads: career-images-b39]

issues.title: Improve career search functionality
issues.description:
Current search is a simple SQL LIKE substring match. Consider improvements:

- Fuzzy matching for typos
- Synonym support (doctor/physician, lawyer/attorney)
- Better relevance ranking
- Possibly full-text search (SQLite FTS5)

Context: Search needs to be useful when demoing the tool to potential collaborators.

[Migrated from beads: career-images-atx]

issues.title: Rename statuses: needs_image → needs_diverse_images, has_image → has_diverse_images
issues.description:
Current status names are ambiguous. 'needs_image' could mean the article has no image at all. Rename to make the diversity goal explicit:
- needs_image → needs_diverse_images
- has_image → has_diverse_images

Requires DB migration and UI updates.

[Migrated from beads: career-images-6ju]

issues.title: Write Wikipedia essay on NPOV for images
issues.description:
Write a formal Wikipedia essay (to be published on Wikipedia) about applying NPOV principles to image selection.

Based on research in docs/NPOV_IMAGES.md, the essay should cover:

1. Why NPOV applies to images, not just text
2. How image selection can introduce bias (e.g., only showing one gender for a profession)
3. Best practices for improving image diversity:
   - Use group photos when possible
   - Use historical pioneers (provides diversity + historical significance)
   - Pair diversity improvements with quality improvements
   - Engage on Talk pages first for contentious articles
4. Case study: 12+ career articles improved 2017-2018, ALL still present 7-8 years later
   - Started with Prime Minister (Nov 2017) - first female PM Sirimavo Bandaranaike
   - Programmer - Ada Lovelace, ENIAC women
   - Judge, CEO, Farmer - group photos
   - Chef, Head of Government, Film Director, etc.
5. Link to existing resources (Wikipedia:Visual representation of women, Gender bias on Wikipedia)

The essay should be suitable for publishing at Wikipedia:NPOV and images or similar.

Reference: docs/NPOV_IMAGES.md contains full research and case study data.

issues.title: Add quick review mode: given an article name, display image thumbnails and metadata for rapid review

issues.title: Show prototype to Anasuya and Alex for feedback
issues.description:
Check with Anasuya on preferred terminology. 'Representative images' might better convey the goal of showing that any career is open to anyone, regardless of background.

[Migrated from beads: career-images-1u3]

issues.title: Consider migrating workflow state to on-wiki infrastructure
issues.description:
From brainstorm: Currently the tool stores workflow state (review status, notes, replacement decisions) in its own database. This could be seen as 'off-wiki coordination.'

Consider moving this to Wikipedia-native infrastructure:
- WikiProject task lists
- Talk page banners (e.g., |image-diversity=needs-review parameter)
- User subpages for personal todo lists

Benefits:
- Transparency (decisions visible to community)
- Avoids 'coordination database' optics
- Integrates with existing Wikipedia workflows

Tradeoffs:
- More friction when reviewing articles
- Requires community buy-in for new banner parameters

Wait for WIR feedback before deciding - they may have opinions on best practices.

[Migrated from beads: career-images-17k]
